thread.title: Mayor puts fire and police departments in charge of Baltimore 911 system
thread.title_full: Mayor puts fire and police departments in charge of Baltimore 911 system

author: Yvonne Wenger
title: Mayor puts fire and police departments in charge of Baltimore 911 system
text:
(Kevin Rector) 
"There have been concerns raised about whether public safety agencies ought to be more directly involved in the supervision of this critical component" of the 911 system, Libit said. "It's been a question of figuring out the logistics of how to make it work." 
The mayor previously announced the city would add the 10 new emergency operators and cut the time to train them from eight months to four. The additional operators are expected to start next month, when another class of five to 10 operators will begin training. 
Rawlings-Blake has said adding operators will address what she sees as the biggest problem facing the system, a 20 percent increase in the number of emergency calls. The call volume is a result of surging violence in recent months. 
Oversight of the 911 was system was shifted to the information technology office in what was billed as an efficiency measure, under a plan to create a centralized emergency operations command center. 
But Libit said that transition was never fully implemented. Fire dispatchers have remained in the Fire Department while police dispatchers and all 911 operators, or call takers, were moved to the information technology office. The operators are the ones who interact directly with the public while the dispatchers communicate directly with police officers and firefighters. 
"The staffing shortages with 911 call takes has exacerbated some of the issues," Libit said. "It's forced us to focus on it."
